flashcards.back: A linearised small-signal equivalent circuit for the BJT, derived from h-parameters by neglecting h_re and h_oe. Contains r_π (input resistance) and g_m·v_be (VCCS).
g_m = I_CQ / V_T ≈ I_CQ / 26 mV (at room temperature). It is independent of β.

flashcards.front: Write the formula for r_π (input resistance).
flashcards.back: r_π = β / g_m = β V_T / I_CQ. It depends on both β and the bias current.

flashcards.front: What is r_e and how does it relate to r_π?
flashcards.back: r_e = 1/g_m = V_T/I_CQ ≈ 26 mV / I_CQ. r_π = β · r_e (the emitter resistance seen from the base is β times larger).

flashcards.front: Why is g_m independent of β?
flashcards.back: g_m = β/r_π = β/(βV_T/I_CQ) = I_CQ/V_T. The β cancels in numerator and denominator. g_m depends only on the Q-point current.
V_T = kT/q ≈ 26 mV at room temperature (27°C / 300 K). k = Boltzmann's constant, q = electron charge. It sets the scale for all small-signal parameters.

flashcards.front: When can R_out be dropped from the model?
flashcards.back: When R_out = 1/h_oe >> R_L (typically R_out > 10 R_L). Since R_out is usually 100k–1MΩ and R_L is 1k–10kΩ, this is almost always valid.

flashcards.front: CCCS form vs VCCS form of the model?
flashcards.back: CCCS: i_c = β·i_b (current-controlled). VCCS: i_c = g_m·v_be (voltage-controlled). Equivalent because i_b = v_be/r_π, so β·i_b = β·v_be/r_π = g_m·v_be.

flashcards.front: Which h-parameters are neglected and why?
flashcards.back: h_re ≈ 0 (negligible reverse feedback from output to input) and h_oe ≈ 0 (output resistance ≈ ∞, doesn't load the circuit).

flashcards.front: When do you use hybrid-π vs r_e model?
flashcards.back: Hybrid-π (r_π at base): best for common-emitter analysis. r_e model (r_e at emitter): best for common-base analysis. Both are mathematically equivalent.
